body: I have tested with celery 4.1.1 and airflow seems to be fine, 4.2 still a release candidate.
@Fokko ping
@Fokko Rebased and ready for another review.
@milton0825  please create a JIRA for this PR since it's more elaborative than fixing a typo. Thanks!
@jgao54 https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-2536 created
thanks!
@jgao54 Can you help merge it? Thanks
Can you please take a look at failing tests in the CI and fix it?
@milton0825  Can you let me know on where do you use this? Just curious to know why you want to over-ride or the specific use-case for you.
@Tagar Can you please squash commits? and as Sid requested can you please provide a little more details on this upgrade in the JIRA?
@jgao54 thanks for the initiative! Could you also review this PR to be included as a part of the dag fetcher?

It looks like 4.2 RC or not should "just work" with apache/incubator-airflow unless I'm missing something.

https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/7c34354427f8c047b2cfb3f472a38bc50fe91d45/setup.py#L118-L121

(We had pinned our fork to 4.0.2.)

I'm happy to copy over this commit https://github.com/astronomerio/incubator-airflow/commit/4fb708cb3ea4284bc66ea992b3b0fe575240bdaa which guards against the next major release of Celery like so `'celery>=4.0.2, <5'` as some other dependencies already do in setup.py.

@Fokko Would it be useful for others for me to send a PR back with that change?

@bolkedebruin , Is this duplicated by #2728 ? 

#2728 is closed.  Both PR's referenced Airflow-1018.
hey Max, I am wondering why we don't want to reset the backfill state back to running after running the clear command?

Well the backfill command has presumably exited by the time the clear command runs. Also I think backfill maintains some internal state and I don't think it would recover nicely from a clear if it was still in-flight.

Anyhow, this requires more thinking, closing for now.
PTAL @mistercrunch

hey @yrqls21 , just curious on how do you solve the `Add Permission to Role Error` issue? I encounter some unit tests errors in my pr(https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3197) as well.
@feng-tao I didn't get to the bottom of that error, it doesn't seem to fail the unit test after all. I saw the error in the existing unit tests also. Joy should know better on this tho.

Thanks @NielsZeilemaker for this change. My suggestion would be to this through the config:
https://airflow.readthedocs.io/en/latest/howto/set-config.html

This will allow us to set it both in the config, and using environment variables.

Cheers

Nice one, lets wait if @mistercrunch has some suggestions.

Please also limit the commit subject line to 50 chars, and give a more elaborate description in the commit body.
@tedmiston @cloneluke As far as I understand, Celery 4.1.0 is broken. So my suggestion would be `>4.1.0, <4.2.0`. I would welcome this PR.
Let me run the tests one more time: https://travis-ci.org/Fokko/incubator-airflow/builds/385586411

Then I'd say a new `airflow.cfg` configuration `DAGRUN_CONF_OVERRIDES_PARAMS = false`, where we may switch the default in `2.0`.
I assume it needs to update the UPDATE.md for every backward incompatible change.
@feng-tao, I'm updating it now, do you have any recommendation about it?

We have to be very careful with changes like this. This will make updating Airflow very hard since you don't only need to upgrade your Airflow instance, but also your DAGs. I think this is fine since the AWS Batch Operator has been introduced after Airflow 1.9, so only people running master need to update their code.

I just sent over a Jira issue + PR in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-2544 / https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3439

I believe `rw` is not a valid mode, but agree with @Fokko that it would be friendlier to determine the mode rather than passing in as argument. My thought is using `r+` instead so it doesn't truncate, but create the file if it doesn't exist since `r+` doesn't create new file.

@mistercrunch I have added a flag `dag_run_conf_overrides_params` in `airflow.cfg`. can you take a look?

I am also leaning towards the idea of switching back to have logging config consolidated back into airflow config. From my observation, the separation seems to have caused quite a bit of confusion since it was implemented.

I recall the original intention of separating logging config and airflow config is to provide more tunable configs on the handler level.  However the handler configs actually are not quite flexible in airflow. For example, the way logging currently works in airflow **requires** root logger to set the handler to console/stdout so that [task handler can pick them up](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/task/task_runner/base_task_runner.py#L134-L140). Another reason is that any logging configurations does not allow them to be set via environment variables. Finally, webserver/scheduler logging config also follow a different pattern (use a separate config filepath that can be passed in the terminal when starting the webserver/scheduler). So right now technically we have 3 ways of configuring logging.

It would be more useful to move the common configs back to airflow.cfg. We could still potentially keep the airflow_local_settings.py to provide advanced logging config, but warn user that they should  'modify only if they know what they are doing' kinda thing.

Thanks for picking this back up. Please use format "[AIRFLOW-XXX] My Airflow PR" for your commit.

Also, please add docs for the hook/operator in docs/code.rst

@milliburn  Given that this is a dupe of #3440 which was created first and is a bit more elaborative (contain both hook and operator), and where a lot of reviews have been put into it previously, we'll probably go with #3440.  Thank you for your time and contribution!

Thanks for the fix! Simpler and cleaner.

I believe you can also remove the following two lines in `airflow/www/views.py`
```
dates = dag.date_range(base_date, num=-abs(num_runs))	
min_date = dates[0] if dates else timezone.utc_epoch()
``` 

Also please take a look at the failing unit test  `test_dag_views ` + pep8
@diogoalexandrefranco just want to check up with you to make sure you are not blocked from the confluence permission issue, and how the design doc is going :)

I want to put this PR on hold and revisited once the fetcher is implemented. Reason being this will need to be extended from the BaseDagFetcher. Merging it now will add unnecessary complication to the fetcher implementation. I'd ask you to add some unit tests but that would be early optimization, given the overall pr will need to adopt the fetcher once that's implemented.

This looks great! Thanks for updating and adding extensive tests.

And yes, we plan to keep both www and www_rbac for 1.10, and deprecate the old UI by 2.0 in order to give everyone a chance to migrate to the new UI.

@gglanzani as far as I can recall, it is that impyla( even the latest version) want thrift <=0.9.3. However the new hmsclient we use in HiveCliHook cannot work with thrift <0.10.0 ( this part I cannot be 100% sure, what I have is that people providing solution saying upgrading it would solve the problem and it indeed solve that problem).

My suggestion would be to modify the 'configuration.get' such that it accepts a default value, and hence we could use:

```
FILENAME_TEMPLATE = conf.get('core', 'LOGGING_FILENAME_TEMPLATE', default_value='{{ ti.dag_id }}/{{ ti.task_id }}/{{ ts }}/{{ try_number }}.log')
```
PTAL @mistercrunch , Max, could you take a look at this pr and see the approach for backfill looks ok?

@Fokko Might it be an idea to use PyHive by Dropbox instead of impyla?

From some basic testing it seems to offer the same impyla API, while being more actively maintained.

Hi @gglanzani 

Yes the problem relies in the fact that your thrift is being compiled against 0.11.0, and Impyla is still at 0.9.3. This causes issues. I've opened up a pull-request, it seems a bit old since they are using PyHive for Python 3.x: https://github.com/cloudera/impyla/pull/303

Cheers, Fokko

@gglanzani Could you do the debugging on your own Travis instead of Airflow's travis? We're having some complaints of Apache Infra of consuming too much time on Travis. If you open a travis on your own account, it is free.

Hi @Fokko, I understand your concerns, during the development sadly I completely forgot about the CeleryExecutor queue capability from Airflow, so I have reused the name that had created a inconvenient need of a worker running on the same queue as AWS Batch.

I have put the warning on the code documentation and also added the breaking chain on the Master section of the UPDATING.md

There's anything else that I need to be compliant with?
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-16602 has now been opened asking the Infra team to migrate us.

Thanks for the comment @Fokko @jgao54! Updated the PR.
Tested with PostgreSQL 9.5.12 and confirmed that it works as follows:

----

0. Initial state:

```
airflow=# SELECT * FROM t;
  c  
-----
 foo
 bar
 baz
(3 rows)
```

```
$ test -f /tmp/t
$ echo $?
1
```

1. Test COPY TO (new file):

```
In [1]: from airflow.hooks.postgres_hook import PostgresHook

In [2]: h = PostgresHook()

In [3]: h.copy_expert("COPY t TO STDOUT", "/tmp/t")
```

```
$ cat /tmp/t
foo
bar
baz
```

2. Test COPY FROM:

```
In [4]: h.copy_expert("COPY t FROM STDIN", "/tmp/t")
```

```
airflow=# SELECT * FROM t;
  c  
-----
 foo
 bar
 baz
 foo
 bar
 baz
(6 rows)
```

3. Test COPY TO (overwrite, # of existing lines in the file < newly output lines):

```
In [5]: h.copy_expert("COPY t TO STDOUT", "/tmp/t")
```

```
$ cat /tmp/t
foo
bar
baz
foo
bar
baz
```

4. Test COPY TO (overwrite, # of existing lines in the file > newly output lines):

```
airflow=# DELETE FROM t WHERE c <> 'foo';
DELETE 4
airflow=# SELECT * FROM t;
  c  
-----
 foo
 foo
(2 rows)
```

```
In [6]: h.copy_expert("COPY t TO STDOUT", "/tmp/t")
```

```
$ cat /tmp/t
foo
foo
```
@jgao54 Thanks for reviewing - I have updated code.rst as well as my commit message

LGTM

Hey @feng-tao, I saw your comment in #3319.  I have seen the `Add Permission to Role Error` in the past but haven't gotten to to the bottom of it. My understanding is that the security manager is trying to add many dupes of (perm, view_menu). First db write works but for each dupe it would violate the integrity error and return `None` (and logs the `Creation of Permission View Error` error but doesn't throw an exception), then it attempts to add the pvm to the role (which is None, so it fails with `Add Permission to Role Error`). 
FYI, this code is in FAB' security manager class, specifically, in the `add_permissions_view` method:
```
            for permission in base_permissions:
                pv = self.add_permission_view_menu(permission, view_menu)
                role_admin = self.find_role(self.auth_role_admin)
                self.add_permission_role(role_admin, pv)
```
It's not a blocker or anything, but still worth investigating. I'll try to take some time next week to dig a bit further. 

In terms of the unit test failure, it's a slightly different issue: `OperationalError: (sqlite3.OperationalError) no such table: ab_permission_view_role`. I suspect the db session object in the unit test doesn't see the FAB-generated tables exist (since we use scoped session). Although this could be fixed in unit test (I haven't taken too close of a look yet), I am suspecting maybe this is comes down to the way I've set up in app.py:

```
db = SQLA(app)
...
appbuilder = AppBuilder(app, db.session, ...)
```

May make more sense to do:
```
from settings import Session
appbuilder = AppBuilder(app,  Session, ...)
```
Thank you @r39132. Apologies for this. Will be careful in the future :)
duplicate to https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3439 please close
LGTM

Getting back to your questions:

1. if i understood correctly, this would mean that the roles are synced only upon (1) starting the webserver (2) when `airflow sync_perm` is called via cli. Otherwise they stay stale. Is that correct? If so, this may be confusing since the scheduler will sync the DAG file but doesn't sync its custom permissions.

2. That's a good question! The migration code is currently in `airflow initdb`, which is an idempotent call, but is only used when first setting up airflow.  Perhaps it's more intuitive to add it in `airflow upgradedb` instead (which initdb calls anyways). Alternatively, we can add them as part of the migration script, The reason I initially didn't go down this path was because FAB itself lazily creates the tables when the application starts. This could become problematic in the future if our models diverge from FAB models, so perhaps its something we want to disable... and use db migration only. I think this is another reason to manager security models in airflow core rather than FAB.  cc @mistercrunch , I think this would address your comment:

> I'm a bit confused as I couldn't find the rbac-related migrations in the repo

3. As discussed in my previous comment. I'll budget some times next week to investigate into the db session side of things as well.
Could you prepend your commit with [AIRFLOW-XXX], will merge after.
I'm okay with this for now, just think at some later point we could make logging more intuitive. @Fokko ?

one nit-pick otherwise lgtm!
I talked to @fokko today, and he suggested moving tge default_value into the configuration file and keeping the configuration.get method as it is now. I'll update the pull request with these changes.

Another thing I've just come to realize is that this PR doesn't yet support parsing access-control in the DAG file.

For example: 
```dag = DAG('mydag', access_control={`role`: [ 'custom_role1'], `perm`: `can_dag_read` }, ...)```


In my head I thought it did because it was in the original proposal, so you can ignore my comment on:

> If so, this may be confusing since the scheduler will sync the DAG file but doesn't sync its custom permissions.

I think this would be a helpful feature since it makes dag-level access control more manageable, but can wait for another pr :)

@feng-tao I am thinking that `backfill` and `trigger_dag` will share the same argument, e.g. `-c, --conf`, to inject parameters to dag_run.conf. Since they are functionally the same, so I am more intend for `backfill` and `trigger_dag` to share the same arg.
